newsitem.title: FRANCE: Cuba rejects shock therapy for economy.
newsitem.headline: Cuba rejects shock therapy for economy.

text.p: Cuba is making economic changes but will never use "shock therapy" tactics to overhaul its economy, the communist country's central bank governor said in Wednesday's edition of the French newspaper Le Monde.

"We're changing as the world has changed," Cuban central bank governor Francisco Soberon told Le Monde in an interview. But "we totally reject shock therapies" espoused by such international bodies as the International Monetary Fund.
At the same time, he said Cuba now believed "a certain level of inequality is inevitable as long as it's not too cruel".

He said the island had been experiencing "a difficult time" since communism collapsed in Europe. This had been aggravated by the "war waged by the United States on all fronts (against Cuba), especially in the area of international finance."
Unemployment, he said, had reappeared for the first time since the 1959 Cuban communist revolution, touching more than seven percent of the active working population.
He said he was reluctant to talk too much about the country's financial state because of the United States' new anti-Cuban law aimed at curbing foreign investment in Cuba.

But he did say Cuban imports were expected to be slightly above $2.5 billion this year, exports just above $1.5 billion and gross revenues from tourism around $1.3 billion this year. He gave no comparative year-earlier figures.
Cuba had made progress cleaning up its finances, he said, having cut money supply by 25 percent in less than three years.
While the banking community viewed Cuba more favourably than in the past, it still suffered from a financing shortage that hurt its ability to invest in the economy, he said.
"We have no choice but to use short term credit, one-year, at rates above those of the market," he said. But "bit by bit, we are getting more medium- and long-term credit."
However, he said the financing Cuba could obtain remained "very insufficent and does not permit us to recapitalize our companies or invest to improve their energy efficiency".

He added that Cuba had implemented a tougher approach to advancing credit to companies. "We're applying a policy of restrictive credit. Cuban company bosses didn't make any difference between a loan and a grant," he said. "Now we're carrying out risk analysis and examining accounts."
He denied this resembled the tight credit policies advocated by the IMF.

"We're doing this out of conviction," he said. "Our philosophy obliges us to take into account the interests of the people and apply reforms in a gradual manner...We will never adopt the neoliberal model."
